The study by Kendall et al. (200

Evaluation of Creative Partnerships (Kendall et al. (2008)
is the national creative learning programme in England, designed
to develop the skills of young people, thereby raising their aspirations and achievements.
Targeted at the most disadvantaged communities in England, the
ogramme brings children and their teachers together with creative organisations and
individuals to work in partnerships on creative projects.
and scientists. These partnerships therefore lead to young people's participation in many
different types of arts participation activities in different schools.
The study used a matched comparison gro
up design and the National Pupil Database.
End of Key Stage 2 and 3 test scores and GCSEs for young people who attended
activities were compared with a matched group of students who did
not attend a Creative Partnerships school.
All three studies measured outcomes for primary school children. Costa
that students who had three years of weekly individual piano instruction had better language
comparison group of students who did not get this instruction.
that students who participated in the National Theatre
than a comparable group of students who did not participate.
compared to similar young people nationally, primary school students who participated in
Creative Partnership activities achieved, on average, the same outcomes in Key Stage 2 tests
as those who did not participate.

For this reason, we interpret the evidence of impact f
Two of authors very generously clarified some issues in order that effect sizes could be calculated.
The author's conclusion that piano instruction did not affect academic achievement in mathematics
appears to have been based on the lack of statistical significance, although this is
not entirely clear in the reporting. The use of different statistical techniques can produce different
values or confidence intervals, which are used by researchers as t
he basis for making a claim of
statistical significance. The synthesis techniques used in this review do not rely on the statistical
